div.head:
Embleme 16. Of the Secrets of Nature.
One weeweLyon weewehath wings, the other none.

lg.l: The weeweLyon prince of beasts in might and sway
Fights without fear, and scornesscorns to weewerunne away:
Give him a Spouse with wings of his weeweowne race,
To mount him with weeweherselfe from place to place;
But weewehee immoved stands, and nulls her force,
By weeweEmbleme to demonstrate Natures course.

div.head: Discourse 16.
div.ab:
It is a thing weeweknowne by experience that a weeweLyon weeweexcells other weeweanimalls not
soe much in weewebignesse and strength of body, as generosity: if weewehee be seen in-
hunting, being ashamdashamed to weewerunne away, weewehee releasethreleases weewehimselfe by degrees,
if weewehee be weeweoppressd by a multitude: being removed from the view of the-
hunters, weewehee makes hast away, thinking it a dishonourdishonor to be excusdexcused by ab
sconding: weewehee desires a wood in flight, which weewehee usethuses, when anything
pursues: his bones are solid and not at all empty, which are weewesayd to be
soe hard, that being shakdshaked together they weeweyeild fire as out of a Steel and-
flint. weeweHee fears fire above all things. weeweHee seems to derive his substance
from the nature of the weeweSunne, for in force and heat weewehee weeweexcells other-
animalls, as the weeweSunne weewedoth the weeweStarrs: Besides weewehee is weeweallways beheld with
fiery and open eyes, as the weeweSunne beholds the earth with an open and-
fiery eye: a LionesseLioness fighting for her whelps fixethfixes her eyes upon the-
ground, that weeweShee may not be weeweafrayd of the hunters Staffs and Spears.-
where a weeweLyon perceives the coition of a Leopard, weewehee takes revenge-
upon the weeweLionesse for adultery, and inflicts severe punnishment;-
The weeweLionesse therefore washethwashes away the offenceoffense and scent in a river,-
or being conscious of the trespassetrespass weewedoth weeweallso accompany the adulterer-
flying for fear of the make: Which weewewonderfull nature of this beast the
Philosophers contemplating, have produced weeweseverall weeweallegoryes of the
Lyon, as it were weewehieroglyphicall writings testifying of their secret-
worke, observing the weeweLyon to be a constant, weewefirme weeweanimall, without-
deceiptdeceit and suspicion, they assimilated the better part of their weewePhi
losophicall composition to him: for as weewehee weeweflyes not, soeso neither this:-
hee with solid bones, soeso this fixed and not to be overcome: and as-
the weeweLionesse is not weeweallways innocent and free from adultery, soeso-
is neither Luna nor Mercury without some blemish, but is weewejoyned
by the ignorant sometimes to this, sometimes to that matter, where
by an adulterous conjunction of things discrepant and different in
nature rather than true matrimony is established: for the products
of a Leopard and weeweLionesse have weewenoe specious and comely mains-
about the weewenecke and Shoulders; with which ensigneensign those generated
by the weeweLyon are alone adorned. The weewePhilosophicall weeweLionesse must
therefore be weewejoyned to her proper mate or male, and a genuine-
and generous whelp will from weewetheme Spring, which may easily
be weeweknowne by his paw. But the weeweLionesse must not be any or-
what you pledge, but winged, which may be able to fight and
contest with the weeweLyon, depending upon the SwiftnesseSwiftness of her-
plumes, lest (to weewewitt) weeweShee Should be oppressed by his extraordi
nary wrath, but to weewethinke upon escape, if at any time weewehee fall
into fury without cause, for weewehee when weewehee stops her flying-
Discourse 16.
is incited with greater love toward her, weewefreindship being made after discord.-
But you will say who ever saw a weeweLionesse with wings, or what can the plumes
of a weeweLionesse weeweavayle? There is a deep valley near the weewemountaine CythærenCytheran,
in which are seen none but flying Lionesse, and at the top of the same-
mountaine resorts a red Lyon of that kind, which Hercules killed. The-
Lyon therefore must be taken, and brought into the valley, and forthwith
coupled to the winged Lionesse: Shee allso will easily suffer herselfe to
be overcome, as like by like: afterwards they must be both advanced
out of the sayd valley to the top of the mountaine, and henceforth they
will never desert one another, but allwayes remaine together in inviolable
amity: The taking of Lyons. I confesseconfess, is not easy, but obnoxious to many-
dangers, weeweneverthelesse it must be attempted: a weeweLyon feeds not with the-
Lionesse, but strayesstrays apart, as story relates, therefore they are to be found and
hunted severally: But if the weeweLyons whelps be weeweobtaind in their infancy, when
they first begin to weewegoe, which is at two weewemoneths age, and be weewejoyned, as weeweafore
sayd, being come to good growth and stature, the thing will be free from-
any danger. Moreover they breed in the Spring time, which must be well
observed: but weeweLyons after whelping using weewecrosse and winding weewewayes, to
prævent the discovery of their denneden, therefore must they be sought and
their whelps taken away very great diligence and care. . . .
